Paragraph.Text: The quiet sounds of wind build to a steady but gentle breeze.
A hand protects some paper from a strong gust. The wind dies down, and the hand starts to write, scribbling lines of poetry on a well-worn notepad.
The hand writes a word, then pauses, then scratches it out. The hand taps its pen on the notepad, thinking. It goes to write another word, but stops halfway through.
It rips the entire page out of the pad and throws the crumpled paper in a nearby dumpster. We return to the notepad, the blank page. The hand taps its pen.
The sound of a door opening. The door that leads out to the alley is labeled “Green Room,” some kind of inside joke.
The hand relaxes, and puts its pen and notebook away.
INT. MEXICAN BAR - WASHINGTON HEIGHTS - NIGHT
The hand pulls a microphone in close, adjusts a stool, tunes an acoustic guitar, plays a chord to test the tuning.
RAY KAPPUS (22) leans into the mic.
Ray sits on a small stage in a dark Mexican bar. The bar is full of chatter that doesn't quiet down as Ray speaks.
My name’s Ray. This song’s about... well it’s about a lot of things, but I wrote it for a girl a long time ago. I, uh, never gave it to her, but hey, at least I've got it.
A COUPLE near the stage--the only people listening--smile.
Ray FINGERPICKS an impressive, upbeat intro. Despite the effort, no one pays it any attention, except for the smiling couple. He leans into the mic and opens his mouth to sing.
Ray ends his set to tepid applause. He grins and bears it.

Text: That's my set. I was Ray Kappus.

Paragraph.Text: A bit more applause as Ray leaves the stage. Suddenly, LOUD LATIN POP begins playing from the house speakers, and several drunkards are compelled to dance now that Ray's off-stage.
The woman from the couple near the stage gets Rays attention.
Ray smiles politely but quickly moves on, preoccupied.
Eventually, he finds who he was looking for: the MANAGER, sitting at the bar with a calculator and a pile of receipts.
Pablo the Manager does not look up from his calculations.
Thank you, yeah, it felt good. So you think it went well?
I’d love to play here again sometime. It’s a great venue--
Ray looks out to see the now enthusiastic crowd dancing wildly to the music.
I’ll call you if we find something.
Awesome. Yeah. Or while I’m here, we could just find a date now--
The manager finally turns to face him.
We'll call you if we need you.
Ray gets the message. He doesn’t know what else to say. The manager sees and sighs.
Kid, look, the show was good. Your songs are really nice. Here.
And how about two free drinks? Come on, sit.
The manager collects his things and gives Ray his seat. He calls to the BARTENDER.
Ray thinks about pursuing the manager, then decides not to.
Ray turns to observe the activity of the bar, the party behind him, the happy couple still seated by the stage.

We're WIDE, viewing the entire activity of the room. Ray is FAST ASLEEP at the bar. We drift toward Ray, time passes, and the crowd dissolves and changes in sluggish timelapse. Intermittently, we see FLASHES of images:

Text.#text: A METAL STRING stretching into black space, OSCILLATING back and forth... A young boy standing in awe before a singing SUBWAY BUSKER... CALLUSED FINGERS closing into a fist and opening... A door BURSTING open to a sunny sky... A GIRL grinning on her stomach, head propped up and staring at us... A house on FIRE... The callused fingers, still opening and closing, now BLOODY... The girl, now looking down, looking away... An immense TIDAL WAVE flooding streets, consuming cars and buildings, getting closer, CLOSER--

Paragraph.Text: Water FLICKS on to Ray’s face as he is awoken from his dream. The bartender continues flicking.
Ray rubs his eyes, groaning hungoveredly.
Ext/int. Taxi cab - somewhere in manhattan - dawn
Ray squints out the window of a cab at the empty city. He takes out his PHONE and turns it on.

Text.#text: EMILY: Hope the gig went well!
MOM: How’s it going, sweetie? I’d love to FT tomorrow.
DAD: Julia’s planning a brunch on Sunday. Can you make it?

Text: Ray stares for a moment, then responds to his DAD:

Paragraph.Text: Ray exits the taxi. He enters his apartment building, the door crammed between a smoke shop and a falafel restaurant.
The front door creeps open, and Ray tip-toes inside. He passes his bed, occupied by a bundled-up, sleeping EMILY (20, frivolous, kind), his girlfriend and a rising senior at NYU.

Text: Ray stands over the bed, considering sleep. Then he gets an ALERT on his phone: “
” in one hour. He silently groans, then walks away from the bed.

Paragraph.Text: Ray’s apartment is full of BOOKS AND PAPERS strewn about. The papers are a mix of sheet music and lyrics. On some of the walls, more poems and lyrics are pasted from floor to ceiling in lieu of wallpaper.

Ray walks into the bathroom. On the mirror is written a QUOTE: “The bird a nest, the spider a web, man friendship.” Ray splashes water on his face and looks at himself in the mirror. He kind of looks like shit.
INT. ALPHABET CITY RARE BOOKS - east village - DAY
Ray still looks like shit as he stands on a ladder examining several rare and dilapidated books on a shelf. This is the Alphabet City Rare Books Shop, Ray's day job.
Directly below him is RUTH (70s, eccentric, endearing), a store regular.
Do you know who wrote it?
I think it’s got a green cover...
Ruth, what’s the book about? Can you tell me that?
It’s a—- I don’t know. It’s kinda magical. But no, more realistic. I think there’s a Mexican, or a Spanish, whatever-—
That’s it! Good boy, Ray. I was remembering my grand-nephew, Zack, that was the “Z.” The book's for his birthday, which is tomorrow.
There should be a few in the back.
Ray leaps off the ladder as Ruth sits at a nearby reading table. She's got a cigarette in hand and flicks a lighter. Ray gently grabs her arm.
Sue me. I'll be right back.
Ray briskly walks through the store, passing by dusty first editions and giant atlases. He scoots around a massive lectern and into the back of the store.
INT. BACK OF bOOKs SHOP - minutes later
As Ray scours the bookshelf, he FaceTimes his mom, LILAH (late 50s, sharp, thoughtful).
...I had a gig last night but, yeah, I slept.
A gig? You should've told me.
Well I'd like to be at the next one, please.
Hey, you working Sunday? There’s a gallery opening in SoHo that I'm supposed to train in for--
I’ve got plans, actually. But I can come out to Long Island next week?
You don't have to do that. I don’t want to stress you out.

Text: A service bell DINGS in the main floor of the shop, just as Ray locates a dusty copy of

Paragraph.Text: Call me later! Love you too!
INT. ALPHABET CITY RARE BOOKS - CONTINUOUS
Ray drops the book on the reading table where Ruth, in the early stages of falling asleep, sits.
He continues to the desk. A MAN looks at a nearby shelf.
Yes, it's a Wordsworth second edition—-
You’re not a student anymore. Just Horacek's fine.
HORACEK (60, polished, boisterous) offers a hand. Ray shakes.
Horacek looks around the barren bookstore.
What about a cup of coffee?
Well I'm supposed to be on shift-—
Ray now looks around. Ruth is the only patron in the store, and she’s fast asleep at the reading table. Horacek notices.
Ray and Horacek are halfway through their coffees.
Sure, there are a few sharp ones this term. But nothing like you guys. Some of those discussions, I mean, those were real fights between young poets. Like with our Ezra Pound unit--

Text: That anarchist girl! Uh, Annie, when she threw the chair. Did

Paragraph.Text: Oh yes. And that final project you did? Your album?
The EP, yes! Fantastic. Adapting Aguilar’s “Gardener” like that--
Really? Hugo Aguilar? I would’ve pegged you as more old-school...
Well he's sort of an old soul, right? At least in his poetry.
I still think about that project. One of my favorites, you know.
Are you giving yourself any room to pursue it? Music, I mean.
I am. I’m taking a gap year--
Good for you. Plenty of time later to go be a doctor.
But, you know, it's a tough industry to break into...
You're certainly not everyone, Ray! I know I’ve only heard the Aguilar songs but—-
You know what you should do? I must still have his address.
I edited a forward he wrote for Ted Pearson a few years back. You should send him the songs.
Come on, Ray! Take a chance. He'll be flattered. Maybe he’s even got a connection in music, who knows?
An alarm goes off on his phone.
I gotta get back. Make sure Ruth hasn’t burned the place down. It was great to see you, Professor.

Text: . And the offer stands if you need it. You have my number.

Paragraph.Text: Thanks. And thanks for the coffee.
Ray leaves. Horacek watches him go, sipping his latté.
Int. ALPHABET CITY RARE BOOKS - evening
It's almost closing time. Ray's attention is split between the ticking of an old grandfather clock and the people walking briskly past outside. Ray MUMBLE-SINGS to himself.
Ruth appears from the back, hair askew.

Text: . Zack still reads at a second-grade level, so--

Paragraph.Text: No problem. Least you slept well.

Ray watches Ruth exit into the passing crowd of pedestrians. In a moment of sustained people-watching, Ray sees a YOUNG WOMAN slow down and stop outside. He looks at her as she studies the sign above the store. Suddenly she peers inside; Ray forces his gaze away from her.
The clock strikes 7:00 PM. Closing time. Ray looks from the clock back to the giant glass window. She's gone.
EXT. Tompkins Square park - east village - EVENING

Text: On his way home from work, Ray checks his EMAILS. He opens his drafts, which include an unsent email with the subject line

Text.#text: Re: Potential gig at The Smokehouse

Paragraph.Text: Ray stops in the middle of the pathway to type. Singing under his breath again, Ray is narrowly avoided by annoyed RUNNERS, TEENAGERS on electric scooters, and DOGS on leashes.
He sends the email. With his neck still craning over his phone, a SOCCER BALL rolls to his feet.
Ray looks up to see a group of boys awaiting the return of their ball. He performs a nice move with the ball, then BOOTS it back to the boys. The ball SAILS through the air--
INT. kiss my axe BAR - BROOKLYN - NIGHT
THWAM, an axe sinks into a wooden target. We're at one of those millennial axe-throwing bars. GROUPS OF 20-SOMETHINGS stand side-by-side, hurling mini-hatchets at a wall as if they were bowling.
Ray and his two best friends, MASON (21, serious, empathetic, naive), and SOFIE (23, effusive, awkward, magnetic) watch from a table, sipping drinks behind the action.
I don't get it. It is therapeutic? Is it athletic? I mean, I really don’t get it.
Everyone's so angry these days, you know? People need to vent.
By throwing tiny axes at a wall?
I mean what else are they gonna do, protest? Start a movement?
Not if you work at the places they're protesting, huh Mace?
It's a living, Ray. You should try it. And anyway, how are you improving the state of the Union?
Okay Bob Dylan. Personally, I think this is just another stupid trend that'll die out in a year or two—
You don’t get shit, Mason. You’re late on everything.

Text: What? Sofie, you didn’t even watch
, Ray, you’re like a hundred years old. Sitting here, drinking bourbon on the rocks, like you're Frank Sinatra.

Paragraph.Text: After a beat, the other two explode into laughter.

Mason and Sofie repeat refrains of 'Rye Kappus!' Playing along, Ray downs his rye dramatically. His friends applaud. Then he motions to an approaching BARTENDER. The bartender reaches their table holding three buckets, full of mini-axes.
The bartender nods, and places the buckets on the table.
And I have three sets of hatchets for Mason.
What? You know the saying, "When in Rome... chuck axes."
INT. Kiss my axe BAR - throwing alley - NIGHT

The three toss mini-axes at targets as they carry conversation. Ray sips discreetly from a waning glass of whisky, which probably shouldn’t be in such close proximity to young adults wielding hatchets.
...So I'm taking Starbucks orders for the office this morning. And one of them's a large coffee with ice for someone named “Andrew.”

There’s only one famous Andrew who asks for ice in his coffee. So when I get back to the office, I’m herded to the conference room. And sure enough, I hand a lukewarm cup of joe to Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber.
Anyway, when I gave him the coffee, I told him about my play, and he told me to send it to his assistant and that he might read it.
Bullseye! I just-- Sorry, yeah. That’s great.
So how's work for you, Ray?
Yeah, how are those rare old books?
Still old. Still rare. Nothing new.
You’ve only been there for a month, how could it be nothing new?
Fuck off! You two're basically the same age.
Not my fault I skipped first grade.
Same shit. No one really listens.
Ray downs his drink. A beat.
The other night I went to a show with some co-workers at that bar we used to sneak into sophomore year.
Oh my god, right! The Bitter End.
Why don’t you go get a gig there?
Yeah, great. I’ll just call up the most famous rock club in New York and tell them that Rye Kappus wants a gig. Right.
Come on, we're just trying to help.
And if any of us had the right connections, we’d be able to.
Bullshit. We’re millennials. Everyone in this bar. And when you get a life-boat, you take it for yourself or the undercurrent fucking drowns you.
Jesus Christ. I'm not trying to--

Now fairly drunk, Ray gesticulates broadly as he speaks, accidentally knocking the bucket of axes off the table. One axe tumbles out in the direction of some people walking by, who jump and shriek a bit. Ray's caused a scene.
The bartender approaches Ray, intending to escort him out.
Sorry man, you had a few too many.
Nah, I've got an early morning tomorrow. Stay. I'll see you guys.
Ray exits. Mason and Sofie look at each other. This isn’t new behavior from Ray. Then, Sofie sees something on the ground.
EXT. Outside of kiss my axe - continuous
Ray leaves the bar. The street is eerily empty. He shivers, then hesitates. He realizes he's forgotten something.
Sofie emerges from the bar with Ray’s coat and hands it over.
There's a beat, Sophie speaks up:
Look, I know things are weird right now. Graduating's weird for all of us. We're all on different tracks... Everybody just wants to know what’s going on with you—-
No, everybody wants to give me advice but no one knows what the hell they're talking about.
Sofie's taken aback. That stung. Ray notices. He sighs.

Text: I'm sorry. I'm being a dick. You're right, we're all on different tracks. I just need advice from someone on

Paragraph.Text: It's not good until someone who matters thinks it's good.
Sofie frowns at this logic, but decides not to push.
Sofie goes back into the bar. As Ray turns to leave, he gets two texts, both from Horacek.

Text: One text is an address in San Sebastian, Spain. The second text is:

Text.#text: "I know it's late, but here's Aguilar's address (he doesn't have email--artists!)... PLEASE reach out!"

Text: But then he pauses, maybe looks back at the bar, and types out a reply:

Paragraph.Text: Ray sits at his desk typing with a vigor we've not yet seen. Nearby, Emily is asleep. He finishes with a pronounced beat.
How do you mail a letter overseas?
Ray is on the phone, looking at a rack of envelopes.
Do you use different stamps? Is it addressed a certain way?
Ray grabs an envelope and walks over to a counter. He goes on his phone to search up "how to address an envelope."
Why don't you ask a postal worker?
Ray looks at the only employee, a sour-looking POSTAL WORKER, clearly not happy with taking the morning shift.
Yes, different stamps. No, just address it normally. Wait-- Who'd you write a letter to? 'Cause if it's someone important, you should really type it up and print it, you know, with your hand-writing.
Ray addresses the letter with extra care to his hand-writing.
Hugo Aguilar. That poet I did my thesis on. And yeah, I bought a printer.
One of my old professors gave me his address. He thinks I should send over some of my lyrics.
Do you know how long a letter takes to get to Spain?
Spain? Um, it could be a few weeks.
Really? I was hoping he'd get the letter before I got another gig.
I'll pay for first-class shipping. That's five days from now. Okay?
Ray receives a notification from Venmo, his mother paying him $44: "For Art's Sake."

Text: old. Let me know what he says!

Paragraph.Text: Ray hangs up. Then he carefully folds up his letter and lyrics, puts them in the now-addressed envelope, seals it.
He approaches the unapproachable postal worker.
I'd like to first-class mail this.
Ray reaches out to hand off the letter. As he does, a STRANGE WIND picks up, lifting the letter out of Ray's hands and into the postal worker's (who has no reaction at all).
The postal worker tosses the letter on a pile of mail behind him. We stay tight on the letter.
First-class? What, you don't have email?
The sound of a jet engine roaring.
EXT. COSTA ROCOSA - PAÍS VASCO - DIA
A FedEx plane flies through the bright blue sky. We tilt down, and as we do a title card appears:

Text.#text: E S P A Ñ A

Paragraph.Text: We continue tilting down until we land on a view of a rocky coastline. Powerful waves CRASH against huge rock formations. Flocks of gulls dive into the sea, looking for a meal. Clifftop grasses ripple in the strong wind.
A pair of TANNED HANDS grip the handles of a RED BIKE. These hands are older than Ray's and a bit more rugged.
HUGO AGUILAR (51) stands next to his bike, facing the ocean, bearing a pleasant smile. His linen shirt whips around him as he takes in the vista and the salt air.
He hears the sound of the plane, looking up as it flies past.

Text: Then, once finished with his moment of zen, he turns around and hops on the bike. He rides away from the sea, past an OLD STONE HOUSE (his
and the only structure in view). In the window, a WHITE-HAIRED CAT watches him go.

Paragraph.Text: Hugo rides a dirt trail away from the house and towards a SMALL CITY in view before him--San Sebastián.
Hugo passes busy locals and unhurried tourists, riding along the white crescent strand of the city’s beach, past the imposing neocolonial city hall, and into the old town.

Text: He passes a man retouching a wall graffiti’d with mug shots of famous Basque separatists under the phrase “
Eventually Hugo stops his bike in front of a building with the signage for

Paragraph.Text: INT. OFICINA POSTAL - SAN SEBASTIÁN - DIA
Key turns... PO box opens... Mail removed...
Hugo glances over a few LETTERS, a couple of royalty checks, a financial notice. Ray's letter is not among them.
Hugo turns to see a Basque woman, ESTI (30s, amiable).

Text.#text: I am learning. It is a strange language.
True. I suppose to you, Spanish must be strange.
When I was young, perhaps. Are you coming to the party tonight?
I think my Basque needs work.
I asked if you were coming to Señor and Señora’s party tonight.
A party? I did not know about this.
There was an invitation in your P.O. box--

Paragraph.Text: Hugo looks through his mail and finds an invitation to a party held by “Sr. & Sra. Cortez Negrón.”

Text.#text: I have it. Forgive me, I do not check my mail very often.
I will think about coming. I must get some work done first.
I hope you can make it. Señor Adebayo will be there too.
Oh, Langston, how terrific! Well, it is wonderful to see you.

Paragraph.Text: Esti nods and departs. Hugo puts the letters in his bag and turns to leave. As he is about to leave, a POSTAL WORKER enters, blocking Hugo's way with an overfilled bin of mail.
Hugo attempts to scoot past, the postal worker stumbles a bit and Hugo notices a letter fall out of the bin.
Hugo points to the letter, then pauses.
The letter is addressed to him, with a return address from Brooklyn, New York City.
Hugo sits outside his usual café, sorting through mail. He opens a letter and reads. We hear a British narration.
Dear Sir Aguilar, I am writing to express my deep admiration for your work and my interest in adapting your voice to the West End stage--
Hugo closes the letter and throws it in a junk letter pile. Next Hugo comes upon Ray's envelope. He considers it for a moment, then places it upon the non-junk pile.
He gets out a notebook and a pen and flips to a blank page. He stares at it for a long while, writing nothing.
A WAITER interrupts him with a cup of scalding-hot coffee.

Text.#text: And could you please rid of these? Thank you.

Paragraph.Text: The waiter leaves with the junk letters (not Ray's). Hugo returns to his notebook. He clicks his pen, staring at the blank page. Eventually he gives up and looks around.
In front of him he sees the sea, and to his right the waiter making an espresso. He looks left and pauses.
He sees a TOURIST COUPLE standing across the street, clearly speaking about him. They cross the road, walking his way. Hugo scribbles down random notes in an attempt to look busy.
Excuse me for intruding, but are you Hugo Aguilar? The poet?
"Gardener" was a transformative experience for her.
The couple laughs, as Hugo just sits there, obstinate.
I think her favorite poem was...
"The Overgrown Man." Ah, she loved it. Said it gave her nightmares!
Hugo nods politely. An awkward beat. Then--
She's at the University of Southern California. USC?
I am not aware of their program.
She studies communications. But she  writes poetry on the side. Oh! Would you have any advice for her?
I do not have much to say--
Of course you would! You’re Hugo Aguilar. Don’t hold back.
She takes out her iPhone and begins to record Hugo
Ehm... You must ask yourself, "Will I die if I do not write?"
Another beat. Hugo escapes into his notebook.
I'm sure you're very busy, but--
We should probably go. It was such an honor to meet you, Mr. Aguilar.
The tourists scurry off as the waiter returns with a glass of ice cubes, which he places on Hugo’s table.

The waiter leaves. Hugo dumps the ice cubes into his still scolding-hot coffee and again picks up the now half-opened envelope from Ray Kappus. He reads the letter briefly, then frowns and tosses it aside, opening up a notebook.
He stares at the blank page.
Soft morning light filters through the windows. Emily is asleep. In the background, we hear Ray noodling on his guitar and mutter-singing to himself.
That stirs Emily. She rubs her eyes and sits up to see Ray sitting by the window with his guitar and a notepad on his lap. He’s furiously erasing something.
Ray turns, and as he does the notepad slips off his lap. He tries to grab it, but slips and half-falls off the chair.
Emily stands, walks over, and picks up the notepad. She reads it while Ray gets back in his seat.
I was trying to get inspired.
You should try meditating. There's this one podcast--
I have meditated. I just get bored. I don’t know, it’s not even like I’m lacking ideas, it’s like my entire creative process needs to change. People aren’t connecting with what I’m saying.
Ray yawns again and reaches for his notepad. Instead, Emily tosses the notepad aside and reaches out her hand to him.
Come to our soft, warm bed.
Emily pulls Ray up, takes his guitar, puts it away, and leads him to bed. They bundle up together under the covers.
You should write a song about sleeping.
Ray thinks for a second, then half-sings:

Text.#text: Sleeping, dreaming through dawn. Thinking of the morning sun.

Paragraph.Text: Maybe I should be the songwriter.
Ray stirs to the sounds of a true crime podcast. Emily’s doing her makeup as she listens. Ray looks for his phone.
Ray stands and walks over to where he was sitting.

Text: Ray finds his phone on the seat and checks it. He sees a calendar alert:

Paragraph.Text: Ray scrambles to dress himself and put on shoes.
I’ve got brunch in fifteen minutes. Ugh. Why didn’t you wake me up?
Why would I? You looked so cute all bundled up. Just chill.
It’s on the Upper East Side.
Ray grabs his phone and keys. He runs out of the apartment...
INT. UPSCALE RESTAURANT - upper east side - LATE MORNING

...and into an upscale restaurant. Ray scans the fancy joint and finds his sisters at their table with drinks. These are JULIA KAPPUS (24, sharp, professional, Bloody Mary) and ABBY ROSE KAPPUS (19, sweet, perceptive, Mimosa).
If I'd known she wasn't coming--
Also late. We got you pancakes.
Frenchie's not coming. And like I was saying, if I would have known she wasn't coming, I would've brought Anthony.
You know how I get around her.
I think Julia wants to hold off on sharing all the stepmother- and divorce-related emotional trauma with Anthony until maybe like, the six-month anniversary.
Julia tosses Ray the drink menu.
EXT. PALACIO NEGRÓN - SAN SEBASTIÁN - NOCHE

Text: Hugo rides up to a beautiful modern
. The sharp horizontal lines of the facade seem somewhat out of place in the neoclassical San Sebastián.

Paragraph.Text: A SERVANT approaches Hugo as he dismounts from the bike.
Mister Negrón has requested that guests speak English tonight, sir.
It's a good thing I've been practicing. Thank you, Enrique.

Text: The servant takes Hugo's bike and Hugo enters the
, crowded with people dressed far better  than him. Across the room he sees one of the hosts, CORTEZ NEGRÓN (50s, sleek, brash, rich) arguing with LANGSTON ADEBAYO (40s, British, permanent smirk).
...the region will never be stable enough for independence. Half of them are Spanish, half of them are French, all they have ever shared is a language and the occasional bottle of

Do you feel bonded with the Americans solely because you share some words?

Text: . The Basques of San Sebastián have far more in common with the Spanish than with French strangers on the other side of the Pyrenees.

Here for a long weekend. Then off to Singapore for business.
Fatima and I will be here until December if the weather holds. We would love if both of you joined us in Cape Town, escape the winter.

Anything you can tell us yet?

Still trying to find something to write about then?
Ah, but when you find it, I know you will be talking the ears off our heads.
Int. UPSCALE RESTAURANT - upper east side - late morning
Abby Rose digs into an omelet, Julia nibbles on avocado toast, Ray eats his pancakes.
School’s fine. I miss home a lot though. I get bored.
I've been trying to put up a mural on campus. But apparently every ugly grey rock on every stupid grey wall is "historically significant."
I just want to do something artsy, like you’re doing with your music. Econ is just so dull.
I mean, I think being a brain surgeon or a CEO's a little cooler than playing cover songs in dive bars but—-
Of course you think that, you have no soul.
Oh, you noticed! I've been trying to get rid of it for years now.
INT. PALACIO NEGRÓN - SALÓN - Más Tarde
Hugo, Langston, and Sr. Negrón are by the bar. Sr. Negrón and Langston are ordering drinks.
Hugo looks across the room, through the collection of guests, to see a mysterious, semi-translucent PALE FIGURE leaning against a wall, in solitude.
What are you seeing, my friend?
Really? Well, I suppose artists do see the world differently.
They all laugh at the joke.
Or perhaps we are all insane.
More laughter. The Ghost drifts into the next room.

INT. UPSCALE RESTAURANT - upper east side - LATER
The siblings have finished their meals. A waiter brings Abby Rose another mimosa. Ray studies Abby Rose’s fake ID.
Mexico City? How does anyone actually believe this thing?

No, I’m okay. Cynthia has me on some diet. I can't eat until 3PM.
I am not being starved, Jules.
A waiter hands the check to Frank.
Nice to see you all got drinks. Even the freshman. So who’s paying for 'em?
I only got orange juice, so...
Sra. Negrón and Hugo enter the library of the house, where THREE PARTYGOERS stand together, sipping drinks and buzzing.
Cortez says we are to be speaking English tonight.
We have been, Fatima, do not worry.
Maria, George, José. Oh! José works in cinema. His first film is in the theaters now, no?
José, maybe you can make a movie out of one of Hugo's short stories.
Oh, I would love nothing more!
That's kind, but I have no interest in adaptions of my work.
A beat. GEORGE (40s, American and determined to prove it) sticks out his hand for a shake.
It's a great pleasure, Mr. Aguilar.
They shake amicably. MARIA (30s, very Spanish) butts in.
Señor Aguilar, I wanted to tell you that I believe you are the greatest Spanish-language poet alive.
Well, I appreciate the belief! But Álvarez is still with us.
Even your English stuff, I'm a big fan. I loved "The Gardener."
A beat of silence that Hugo does not try to fill.
I wanted to ask a question.

Text: He is wondering, once you finish a poem—-

Paragraph.Text: José smiles, then turns to Hugo.
After you complete a work, such as "Gardener," do you feel you have gotten closer to the truth?
Everyone looks towards Hugo. He takes a moment to think, and then begins to think out loud.

Text: The more I write and the older I grow, I find myself puzzled by the notion of a search. Of a goal. If there

such a goal, I certainly do not know what it looks like, so how would I know when I have found it? No. After I work, mostly I find myself tired, and often more lost than when I began. But I also find satisfaction. It is as such when Lucas,

reaches for an itch that he finally manages to scratch. But then, when one itch is scratched, another appears somewhere else. And since I am paid to sit at a typewriter and scratch all day and night, I will return to writing, always. Whereas if Lucas continues to scratch, I must take him to

Paragraph.Text: Hugo's joke falls flat. A pause.
Ehm... I'm sorry. It is a difficult thing, to talk about art.
Well, then, why do you write?

Text.#text: I do not know, sir... Do you know why you produce a film?

Paragraph.Text: Sensing hostility, Sra. Negrón jumps in--

Text: It was an interesting reply. I am not sure how well I understand, but

Paragraph.Text: The friends begin to talk amongst themselves, and they quickly forget about Hugo.
Hugo, eager to be somewhere else, looks about the room, at the books towering above him, at the strangers all around, until his gaze lands on a lone figure:
The Ghost, drifting unnoticed through the crowd.
EXT. UPSCALE RESTAURANT - upper east side - LATER
Frank, Ray, Julia and Abby Rose walk out together.
Got a gig we can all come to soon?
Actually, I'm supposed to hear back about something on Monday night at the Smokehouse.
I probably won't even get it.
You should bring Tony. We'd love to meet him.
Don't call him Tony. He hates that.
Now I’m definitely calling him Tony.
Can you give me a ride to class?
Yeah. Gotta pick up a cake up there for Tony’s nephew's birthday.
Julia and Abby Rose each embrace their father and leave.
Back to work. You mind if I Uber? I’m still on your account.
I'm trying to finish a new song tonight. Been trying for ages.
You'll get it. And how's the girlfriend?
I mean, it's kinda hard to focus on writing when she stays over, but--
How often is she staying over?
More often than not. She gets magazines delivered there now.
You'll figure it out. A little more here, a little less there--
Do you, uh, remember Mark Roberts?
One of them, yeah. We reconnected on Facebook and I found out he’s an executive at some big music label in the city. I could hook you two up for coffee or something--
Honestly Dad, another coffee isn’t gonna do me any good.
What if I invited him to the gig on Monday? It’d be casual.
I don't even know if I got it yet. And I doubt he’d come--
But it’s worth the ask, right?
I’m excited for this new song. What’s it about?
Ray enters the Uber, and it drives away.
Esti unlocks a wrought iron gate, behind which stands Hugo’s bike. Hugo enters and retrieves it.
Esti shakes her head. She whispers:

Text.#text: Señor Negrón does not like it when I speak Basque.
Ah. Well, thank you for the help.
Of course. But why leave so early? Before dinner, even!
I... feel out of place. I am in a strange mood tonight.
My grandmother was a moonchild. During full moons she always felt an intense sense of longing. As if she should be up there, not here.

Paragraph.Text: Hugo looks up at the moon, shining, full.

Text.#text: Perhaps that is it. But I should not keep you any longer.
Come back soon! I know the Negróns would love to see you more!
Of course. And you must help me with my Basque.

Paragraph.Text: Esti goes inside. Hugo mounts the bike and attempts to ride, but he’s too drunk and can’t keep straight. Eventually he gives up and dismounts, chuckling to himself.
Hugo then notices the Ghost standing a few yards away, staring at the moon. He watches for a moment, then speaks.
The streets of San Sebastián are active but not crowded as people flock to pubs, bars, and the occasional club.
Hugo, pushing his bike, accompanies the Ghost on a nighttime stroll through the city’s streets.

Text.#text: NOTE: The Ghost does not speak, per se. His words are shown as subtitles accompanied by sounds of wind and old things.

Paragraph.Text: You are Austrian? What are you doing so far from home?
The Ghost takes a moment to respond.

Text.#text: I died in Switzerland and found myself wandering for many years under its mountains. But after so long in such stolid darkness one desires the opposite. So I came to the bright, impetuous ocean.

Paragraph.Text: Hm? Ah, you mean Mexico. They do not love me there. The Catholics think I am a pagan, the scholars think I am a relic--

Text.#text: No prophet is accepted in his own country.
Blake says all poets are prophets.

Paragraph.Text: Plato says all poets are liars.

Text.#text: I should say, most who see me are not so friendly as you.

Paragraph.Text: Well, you are not the first spirit I have known.
Hugo and the Ghost have left the town center now, the streets here are largely deserted.
Under those mountains, did you find anything?

Text.#text: Fossils long since turned to stone. Veins of gold and silver kilometers long. Nothing of great interest.

Paragraph.Text: What interests you if not gold and monsters?

Text.#text: People. Their daily routines. The endless mystery of their lives.

Paragraph.Text: I used to feel the same. But my art demands solitude and an interest in Things and Nature. I found that I have lost patience for most people.

Text.#text: In death, I see the living in a way I never could before.

Paragraph.Text: Hugo pulls out Ray's letter from his bag.
From an admirer, another poet. A decade ago I would have responded immediately. But for some reason now, I hesitate.
He asks for advice. The young man feels stuck, trapped in a mire, and he wants me to help pull him out. But how can I do this? Who am I to tell him how to be an artist?

Text.#text: You are an artist. A master of your trade. It is your duty to pass on knowledge to the youth.

Paragraph.Text: Regardless, he is a musician. I know nothing about music.

Text.#text: Yes. Though my teacher was not, he was a sculptor. He could not teach me to write a sonnet; yet he taught me to see the world clearly and to live as an artist. Without him I could not have been who I was.

Paragraph.Text: I have tried to give advice, insight. It falls on deaf ears.

Text.#text: If this young man is a true artist, he will understand.

Paragraph.Text: The two reach what could be called the edge of the city. Beyond them, a road stretches along the rocky Basque coast.
The Ghost nods and moves forward, Hugo joins him.
INT./EXT. UBER - somewhere in manhattan - DAY

Text: The Uber moves through New York traffic. Ray writes on his notepad, mouthing along to words in his head. He writes down the lyrics:

Text.#text: "Sweet and soft in too lucid a dream."

Paragraph.Text: Satisfied with the line, he takes a break and looks out the window, taking in the blur of the passing city.
As he looks out, we notice the just-penned letters of the lyrical phrase BEGIN TO MOVE, creeping along the page like a caterpillar towards the edge of the notepad.
Ray finishes his break and looks down at the paper again. The phrase is now missing from the page. Ray looks up to see his lyrics FLOATING IN THE AIR next to him.

Text: The letters are just floating there. Ray gives them another look. Then he frowns, realizing something. He summarily grabs the letters and drags them back to the page. He scratches out

Paragraph.Text: EXT. CASA DE HUGO - PAÍS VASCO - AMANECER

Text: Hugo finishes a joke and belly laughs while the Ghost smiles subtly. They approach Hugo's
and stop at the gate, admiring the lightening sea and sky as dawn rises.

Paragraph.Text: I love Basque Country. Here I am steeped in the sublime.
Would you like to come inside--?
Hugo turns to see the Ghost drifting toward the rocky cliff. Slowly, the first rays of dawn appear, illuminating the Ghost. He vanishes in the light. Hugo watches with interest.
The wind seems to pick up for a moment in response.
Hugo’s cat, Lucas, greets him as he enters. Hugo gives him a scratch, then approaches a table by a window facing the sea.
Hugo dumps his mail on the table and sits, yawning widely. He picks up Ray’s letter, still unsure about it. Lucas hops on the table. Hugo scratches him and reads the letter.
He's interrupted by a ringing landline. He answers.

Text: ? ... Yes, good morning Arnoldo. ... I saw the letter, and no, I am not interested. ...  No. No options, no adaptations, no collaborations. They are just distractions from the work. ... No, nothing to send over at this moment, but -- Well, I have been up all night. Please excuse me.

Paragraph.Text: Hugo hangs up and finishes reading Ray's letter. He stays with it for a moment, then yawns again and looks towards the room’s bed for a long beat.
Hugo turns his head back to the table--and to the letter.
int. ALPHABET CITY RARE BOOKS - east village - afternoon

Ray stands at the front desk, his notebook of lyrics in front of him. He taps a pen and hums a tentative melody. He stops partway through, corrects a bad note, and hums the rest of the line. He gets out his phone and records the melody again in full, more confident this time.

Text.#text: "Staring daggers at my hands, this is all that I am, this is all..."

Text: Ray's phone starts ringing in his hand. The call is from

Paragraph.Text: Hello? ... Yes. ... Yes! Of course! Thank you. ... Yeah, I'll bring bodies, for sure. Ten or fifteen. Great ... See you Monday!

Text: Ray hangs up. He exhales in relief. Then he goes back to his voice-memo app and names the file he just made:

Paragraph.Text: INT. BACKSTAGE of THE Smokehouse - midtown - evening
Ray tunes his guitar in the wings of the stage. Curious, he peeks out from the wings. The Smokehouse is a sizable venue, and it's pretty packed.
Ray catches a glimpse of his father sitting with his second wife, CYNTHIA DECHAMPS-KAPPUS (45, French, charming), and their guest, MARK ROBERTS (60, a suit), who is on the phone.
Ray returns to nervous plucking, checking on the crowd here and there, mumble-singing to himself.
Mason and Sofie stand at the bar, waiting for drinks.
So that guy with Ray’s dad is...?
Damn. Ray must be shitting himself.
Yeah, the only opinion here Ray actually cares about.
Over at the adults' table, Mark gets off the phone.
Of course. Now Mark, as I was saying, can you believe that Frank has never been to Paris?
I was there for a day, alright?

Text: Three hours in Roissy for a layover. My family has had a home in Saint-Germain since
has never seen it. We've tried two times but something always comes up.

Paragraph.Text: I think he's avoiding it. I think he knows that if we went, we would never leave.
I am sure you've been to your wife's home city, Mark.
They laugh. Abby, Emily, Julia and ANTHONY (27, stiff, handsome, quiet) arrive with their drinks.
And red for-- Sorry. I don't know--
Oh. Nice to meet you. Anthony.
And an Old Fashioned for Mark.
Sorry, girls. You know, I don’t think I’ve seen you kids since your father's and my 20-year reunion.
They do a fantastic job making us feel quite old, don’t they?
The grown-ups laugh. The kids groan silently and sit down.
Abby Rose, that better be lemonade.
So yeah, Ray totally redid his set.
He just switched out a song and changed the order.
It's crazy. I totally remember him at that reunion. One of those kids always singing under his breath.
Couldn’t help himself. He’s been writing songs since he was five. Still sings everywhere he goes.
Which gets annoying. But it was probably cute when he was a baby.
Dad texts her when Ray's got a gig.
Oh no, I completely forgot. For some reason I thought Ray would.
Abby Rose, frustrated, looks around. She spots Ray’s friends.
Your father can’t do a million things.
I can text her right now, but I think she’s out of town.
Abby Rose stands up and migrates toward the bar and Ray’s friends. They see her approach and Sofie embraces Abby Rose. Mason sits up straight, fixes his hair.
Hey, Abby. It's good to see you.
Both of them linger on their mutual smiles.
INT. Backstage of THE Smokehouse - CONTINUOUS

Ray is peeking out at the audience as he fiddles with the strings of the guitar. He can't help but think about the potential of this evening, this performance. A nervous rush overcomes him. Ray runs toward the back-door and slides out.
EXT. ALLEY of the Smokehouse - EVENING

Ray steps out of a door behind the bar with his guitar on his back. His face has gone pale. He takes deep, haggard breaths to calm his nerves, but something comes over him and he runs and VOMITS into a nearby trashcan.

Ray wipes his mouth and stands up. Behind him, having appeared from nowhere, we see the outline of a young woman leaning against the wall, HOPE (20s, hipster out of a movie). She smokes a VAPE, and the thick vapor as she exhales surrounds her strangely, obscuring her features.
He spits and pulls out a cigarette, half-ignoring Hope.
Ray lights his cigarette and takes a long drag.
I don't know. Feels like everything's out of control.
Eh, control's overrated. You know what kinda person needs to be in control all the time? A fascist. You a fascist?
Hope takes a long drag. The vapor wraps itself around her.
I wanna see if you're any good.
Ray isn't sure. But he puts out his cigarette anyway. He swings his guitar around and begins to fingerpick a tune.
Immediately, Hope starts to "boo" Ray. He stops playing.
After a beat, Ray starts over. He shuts his eyes and sings.

Text.#text: Fall in a stare to alight//  Tell me why it's so close.//  Before you dissolve in the night, I know//

Paragraph.Text: As Ray sings, the vapor obscures Hope further until we're left with only the image of red lips in a sideways smile.
Ray opens his eyes to look at Hope, but she's gone. Vanished like smoke or vapor. Or a ghost. We cut to...

...Ray singing the rest of the song. As he sings, we track various connections in the crowd. Frank to Cynthia (and Mark), Julia to Anthony (well, Anthony to Julia), Abby Rose to Mason, Emily to Ray, and Sofie to Ray.

Text.#text: I made you in my mind.//  Eyes that bleed blue in the light, lifelike//  Meaningless details now, and then//  But it all felt so profound when// I made you in my mind.//   Not long now before dawn.//  And you erode away//  And the sweetest sound you made, fades//  Staring daggers at my hands, this is all that I am, this is all//  Cursed to know why it just doesn't feel right when I fall//  The sound soft and sweet in too lucid a dream, and it all//  Fades.

Paragraph.Text: The song ends to thunderous applause.
INT. THE Smokehouse - After the set
Ray stands in a circle near the bar with his friends, with his girlfriend, and with his sisters and Anthony.
...And that new song. Ray, God, it was beautiful.
I'm okay for now, thanks bud.
We haven’t met yet, but I’m—
My sister’s told me all about you. Tony, right?
Abby Rose and Julia share a look.
We're so proud of you, Ray.
Ray leaves to go to Frank’s table, where Frank and Mark hold a quiet conversation. Cynthia steps into Ray’s path.

Text: Call me Mark. You grew up, man! I should be calling

Paragraph.Text: Why don't you two have your talk another time? You should bask in this. You were great up there.
Sure. Frank, how about a few beers?
Frank and Cynthia leave Mark and Ray to their conversation.
So... I mean, what can I say? You’ve got a beautiful voice. And you can really play.
That’s awesome. Coming from you, especially. Thank you.
And you should be proud of that.
Want me to be brutally honest?

I know you're looking to make a career, son. And you’ve got real talent, seriously. But you're not exactly what the industry's looking for right now. The moody white guy with a guitar... You're going to have to fight against that image. And the songs are good, but the lyrics don’t make sense. It's like you're writing pop songs as a folk artist with-- I don’t even know what those lyrics are. Like poetry?
Hey, your dad told me you got into NYU Med. That's impressive.
My cardiologist plays jazz on the weekends. Maybe you can do both!
Frank and Cynthia return with beers.
I’m sorry Ray, I forgot to—
Did you and Mark talk? Helpful?
He told me his cardiologist plays jazz on the weekends.
Frank can see the mess he's made by inviting Mark. Ray steams in silence. The rest of Ray's fan club swarms him.
So we were thinking of maybe going out to celebrate Ray.
One of my co-workers is hosting a warehouse party in the Navy Yard.
No way! This culture podcast I'm into said those are awesome.
Maybe he'll even suspend his stupid shoes-off policy for us...
Amidst the excited conversation, Ray quietly slips out of the group. Sofie notices, but too late. As Ray leaves the bar, the next act speaks into the microphone:
Give it up for the opener tonight. Wasn't Ray great?

Ray speeds toward the subway station. The city is alive tonight. Ray, holding his emotions hard inside, cuts through myriad groups of people, all flowing downstream as he fights to go up. He eventually dips into the Subway.

On the subway headed back to Brooklyn, Ray checks his phone. Texts from Emily and Abby Rose and his Dad and Sofie flood his screen; they're worried. He scrolls through these notifications and reaches a Missed Call and Voicemail from “Mom.” He presses it and puts the phone to his ear.

Hi boy. It’s your Mom. I think your Dad forgot to tell me about the gig tonight. Julie texted but I’m just now getting out from parent-teacher conferences and I couldn’t make it over. Please don’t feel bad for not telling me--God, that sounds passive aggressive. Don't feel bad at all. I know how much is happening right now, even if it seems like nothing's happening. It’s a lot of pressure: a gap year to pursue your dream. Just know that I love you no matter what the year is. No matter who you become.
Ray breaks down into the phone.
And I hope you had fun playing tonight. That’s what matters.
EXT. JARDÍN de hugo - PAÍS VASCO - MAÑANA
Hugo, still in his pajamas, waters his plants. He’s a bit hungover, and perhaps not the best gardener, ironically.
Soon, it begins to drizzle outside. Hugo looks up, amused. He sticks out his tongue and stands there for a while.
Just as it's about to really pour, Hugo drops his watering pail and heads back to his house.
INT. CASA DE HUGO - COCINA/OFICINA - MAÑANA
Hugo puts on a pot of coffee. Lucas meows out of hunger.

Hugo plates an assortment of fruit and ham. He turns on the radio, which plays a Spanish guitar instrumental. Hugo begins to dance ever so slightly. In his movement, his gaze goes toward the typewriter, sitting stale at his desk. He walks toward it.

Once at his desk, he begins to type a few words. Soon, he finds his rhythm, and the pressure he puts on each tap of the keyboard mounts. He passionately presses down onto the space bar, and it breaks off, falling to the floor.

After a beat, Hugo picks it up off of the ground and stares at it, laughing, before tossing it in the trash. He then opens a drawer in his desk, which contains a toolkit and an organized set of replacement typewriter keys.

Text: The door opens. Ray trudges in, walking to the center of the room. He notices a wine bottle on the table with a note attached. It reads:

Ray rips the note off and throws it onto a pile of mail. He unscrews the bottle but suddenly pauses. He sees under Emily’s half-ripped note a letter with a large stamp depicting a Basque pelota player under a word:

Paragraph.Text: Slowly, he puts the bottle down and picks up the letter. The name on the return address is "Sr. Aguilar."

Text: MUSIC UP: The GUITAR INSTRUMENTAL plays in Ray's apartment as score, while playing as source in Hugo's

Paragraph.Text: He gingerly, reverently opens the envelope. He removes the letter, typewritten. He sits, and reads:

Dear sir. Your letter arrived just a few days ago. I want to thank you for the great confidence you have placed in me. That is all I can do. I cannot discuss your verses; for any attempt at criticism would be foreign to me. Nothing touches a work of art so little as words of criticism: they always result in more or less fortunate misunderstandings. Things aren't all so tangible and sayable as people would usually have us believe.
INT. Casa de hugo - COCINA/OFICINA - MAÑANA

Hugo replaces the typewriter’s broken spacebar. For a moment, he is satisfied with his handiwork. Then, he starts to replace the ink, and soon other keys as well, carefully lifting and replacing the caps of ones that have been worn out. Concurrent with this is his voiceover:

You ask whether your verses are any good. You ask me. You have asked others before this. I beg you to stop doing this sort of thing. You are looking outside, and that is what you should most avoid right now. No one can advise or help you--no one.
Finally finished, Hugo stares at his typewriter, content with his repair. Lucas meows, hungry. Hugo obliges the cat and takes leave from his typewriter. Concurrently:

So, dear Sir, I can't give you any advice but this: to go into yourself and see how deep the place is from which your life flows; at its source you will find the answer to the question of whether you must create. Accept that answer, just as it is given to you, without trying to interpret it. Perhaps you will discover that you are called to be an artist.

He returns to the kitchen to fetch his plate of food and pours himself a coffee. He sits at his dining room table. It’s drizzling rain, but the sun is shining brightly beyond the clouds. Lucas climbs onto the table. Hugo takes a bite of an apple slice and feeds the rest to Lucas. Concurrently:
Then take that destiny upon yourself, and bear it, its burden and its greatness, without ever asking what reward might come from outside.
Hugo looks out the window at the Ghost, standing in his garden. The Ghost nods at him, Hugo nods back.
Ray is still reading the letter, still gripped.
For the creator must be a world for himself and must find everything in himself and in Nature, to whom his whole life is devoted.

As he finishes the passage, a strange wind picks up, almost unnoticeable. It builds as Ray's attention turns to the walls of his apartment, discovering that the words written on the poems/lyrics/books pasted everywhere are flying, literally, off of their pages. Letters separate from their paper confinement and take up space in the third dimension.

But after this descent into yourself and into your solitude, perhaps you will have to renounce becoming a poet (if, as I have said, one feels one could live without writing, then one shouldn't write at all). Nevertheless, even then, this self searching that I ask of you will not have been for nothing. Your life will still find its own paths from there, and that they may be good, rich, and wide is what I wish for you, more than I can say.
The papers are pulled off of the walls and begin to fly about the room. Ray stands and reaches for the letters. Music swells as letters and papers swirl around Ray in a flurry.

I thank you once more for your questions and sincere trust, of which, by answering as honestly as I can, I have tried to make myself a little worthier than I, as a stranger, really am. Yours very truly...
Ray shuts his eyes. He folds the letter and holds it tightly. The papers and letters around him become still in space. He then opens his eyes, taking in the frozen scene. Mesmerized.
Then, all at once, a final chord rings out, and the pages and letters plummet to the ground, like heavy rain.
